column5: romanized: aṛṛbaṭ) is the capital city of Morocco and the country's seventh largest city with an urban population of approximately 580
column6: 000 (2014) and a metropolitan population of over 1.2 million. It is also the capital city of the Rabat-Salé-Kénitra administrative region. Rabat is located on the Atlantic Ocean at the mouth of the river Bou Regreg

column1: Rabat was founded in the 12th century by the Almohad ruler Abd al-Mu'min as a military town. The city steadily grew but went into an extended period of decline following the collapse of the Almohads. In the 17th century Rabat became a haven for Barbary pirates. The French established a protectorate over Morocco in 1912 and made Rabat its administrative center. Morocco achieved independence in 1955 and Rabat became its capital.

column2: Temara
column3: and Salé form a conurbation of over 1.8 million people. Silt-related problems have diminished Rabat's role as a port; however
column5: and Salé still maintain important textile
column6: food processing and construction industries. In addition
column7: tourism and the presence of all foreign embassies in Morocco serve to make Rabat one of the most important cities in the country. The Moroccan capital was ranked at second place by CNN in its "Top Travel Destinations of 2013". It is one of four Imperial cities of Morocco
column8: and the medina of Rabat is listed as a World Heritage Site. Rabat is accessible by train through the ONCF system and by plane through the nearby Rabat–Salé Airport.

column1: The name Rabat comes from الرِّبَاط (ar-ribāṭ) meaning the ribat
column2: an Islamic base or fortification. This name is short for رِبَاط الفَتْح (ribāṭu l-fatḥ) meaning the ribat of conquest or stronghold of victory—a title the city acquired in 1170
column3: due to its military importance.

column1: Rabat has a relatively modern history compared to the nearby ancient city of Salé. In 1146
column2: the Almohad ruler Abd al-Mu'min turned Rabat's ribat into a full-scale fortress to use as a launching point for attacks on Iberia.

column1: Yaqub al-Mansur (known as Moulay Yacoub in Morocco)
column2: another Almohad Caliph

column5: Yaqub died and construction stopped. The ruins of the unfinished mosque

column1: Yaqub's death initiated a period of decline. The Almohad empire lost control of its possessions in Spain and much of its African territory
column2: eventually leading to its total collapse. In the 13th century
column3: much of Rabat's economic power shifted to Fez. In 1515 a Moorish explorer
column5: reported that Rabat had declined so much that only 100 inhabited houses remained. An influx of Moriscos
column6: who had been expelled from Spain
column7: in the early 17th century helped boost Rabat's growth.

column1: Rabat and neighboring Salé united to form the Republic of Bou Regreg in 1627. The republic was run by Barbary pirates who used the two cities as base ports for launching attacks on shipping. The pirates did not have to contend with any central authority until the Alaouite Dynasty united Morocco in 1666. The latter attempted to establish control over the pirates
column2: but failed. European and Muslim authorities continued to attempt to control the pirates over many years
column3: but the Republic of Bou Regreg did not collapse until 1818. Even after the republic's collapse
column4: pirates continued to use the port of Rabat
column5: which led to the shelling of the city by Austria in 1829 after an Austrian ship had been lost to a pirate attack.

column1: The French invasion of Morocco began in the east with General Hubert Lyautey's occupation of Oujda March 1907 and in the west with the Bombardment of Casablanca August 1907. The Treaty of Fes established the protectorate March 1912. Acting as French administrator of Morocco
column2: Lyautey
column3: decided to relocate the country's capital from Fes to Rabat. Among other factors
column4: rebellious citizens had made Fes an unstable place. Sultan Moulay Youssef followed the decision of the French and moved his residence to Rabat. In 1913
column5: Lyautey hired Henri Prost who designed the Ville Nouvelle (Rabat's modern quarter) as an administrative sector. When Morocco achieved independence in 1955
column8: chose to have the capital remain at Rabat.

SAC felt the Moroccan bases were much less critical with the long range capability of the B-52 Stratofortresses that were replacing the B-47s and with the completion of the USAF installations in Spain in 1959.With the USAF withdrawal from Rabat-Salé in the 1960s

column10: a status it continues to hold.

column1: Rabat features a Mediterranean climate (Csa) with warm to hot dry summers and mild damp winters. Located along the Atlantic Ocean
column2: Rabat has a mild
column3: temperate climate
column4: shifting from cool in winter to warm days in the summer months. The nights are always cool (or cold in winter
column6: with daytime temperatures generally rising about 7–8 °C (13–14 °F). The winter highs typically reach only 17.2 °C (63.0 °F) in December–February. Summer daytime highs usually hover around 25 °C (77.0 °F)
column8: especially during heat waves. Summer nights are usually pleasant and cool
column9: ranging between 11 °C (51.8 °F) and 19 °C (66.2 °F) and rarely exceeding 20 °C (68.0 °F). Rabat belongs to the sub-humid bioclimatic zone with an average annual precipitation of 560 mm (22 in).

column1: The places of worship are predominantly Muslim mosques. The last remaining synagogue in Rabat is the Rabbi Shalom Zawi Synagogue. There are also Christian churches and temples
column2: including an Evangelical church and St. Peter's Cathedral
column3: which hosts the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Rabat.

column1: ONCF operates the Le Bouregreg urban rail for Rabat-Salé agglomeration.
The Rabat-Salé tramway is a tram system which was put into service on May 23
column2: 2011 in the Moroccan cities of Rabat and Salé. The network has two lines for a total length of 19 km (12 miles) and 31 stops. It is operated by Veolia Transdev with Alstom Citadis trams.

column1: Prince Moulay Abdellah Stadium (Arabic: مركب الأمير مولاي عبد لله) is a multi-purpose stadium in Rabat
column2: Morocco. It is named after Prince Moulay Abdellah. It was built in 1983 and is the home ground of ASFAR (football club). It is used mostly for football matches
column3: and it can also stage athletics. The stadium holds 52
column4: 000. Since 2008 it is host of the Meeting International Mohammed VI d'Athlétisme de Rabat.
